Expert Microwave Repair for Over-the-Range and Built-In ModelsWhen your microwave stops working, it disrupts more than your cooking—it interrupts your routine. Whether you have an over-the-range microwave that won’t heat or a built-in model with an unresponsive control panel, the appliance repair experts at Sears Home Services are here to help.
Our certified technicians service all major brands including GE, Whirlpool, Kenmore, Frigidaire, Panasonic, and more. From fixing door latches and replacing magnetrons to diagnosing turntable and keypad problems, we provide fast, reliable, in-home appliance repairs backed by years of expertise.
We understand that a microwave is a daily essential. That’s why we offer:

Comprehensive repair services for over-the-range and built-in microwave models
Expert diagnostics to determine the root cause of failures
Genuine manufacturer parts whenever possible for long-lasting results
Service across the U.S. with convenient appointment scheduling online or by phone

Don’t put up with a microwave that isn’t working right. Schedule your microwave repair service with Sears Home Services today and get your kitchen running smoothly again.
Common Microwave Problems We Repair
Microwave runs but won’t heat food
If your microwave powers on, the light turns on, and the turntable spins—but your food stays cold—you’re not alone. This is one of the most common microwave repair problems, especially with over-the-range and built-in units.
Several components are responsible for generating the heat inside your microwave. When one fails, the unit may appear to operate normally but won’t actually cook your food. Common causes include:

Magnetron failure – The magnetron produces the microwave energy that heats food. If it burns out, the appliance will run but not heat.
Defective high-voltage diode or capacitor – These parts work with the magnetron to create energy. If one fails, you’ll often hear humming or buzzing while food remains cold.
Blown internal fuse or faulty control board – Sometimes the issue is electronic. A failed control board may send power to the fan and turntable but not to the heating system.

You’ll need to schedule appliance repair service to fix these types of microwave failures.
Control panel not responding or showing error codes
When the control panel is dead or isn’t responding, the main electronic control board or the control panel component itself could be defective. A wiring failure could also prevent the control panel from working.
When you’re seeing an error code on your microwave, look up the code in the owner’s manual for possible solutions. If you’re not able to resolve the problem and clear the microwave error code yourself, you’ll need to schedule repair service.
Turntable not spinning
Check the turntable setting to make sure rotation is enabled. Adjust the turntable alignment if the coupling rotates but the glass tray doesn’t spin.
If the coupling doesn’t rotate, pull it off and check for damage. Replace the coupling if it’s worn or damaged.
If the coupling motor shaft doesn’t rotate, the turntable motor may be bad.
If you’re unable to find and fix the cause of the turntable not spinning, have a technician diagnose the failure and repair the microwave.
Loud buzzing or unusual noises
Loud buzzing noise in a microwave is often caused by a bad magnetron, defective diode, or malfunctioning cooling fan. Clunking or rattling noise can be caused by problems with the turntable such as a worn coupler or damaged roller guide.
Door not latching or staying closed
Damaged door hooks or catches can prevent the door from latching properly or staying closed. It’s best to have a microwave technician examine the door components and correct this type of failure.
Arc marks and burnt spots inside the microwave cavity
Some of the common causes of arc marks and burnt spots inside your microwave are food spattered on the liner that is not cleaned off, incorrect rack usage during cooking and aluminum foil or metal getting too close to the side during cooking.
For microwaves that are not stainless steel on the inside, you can repair arc marks up to the size of a quarter using this touch-up paint, but only if the marks appear on the inside walls, the floor, or the ceiling. If you’re confident in your DIY repair abilities, follow the steps in this video to repair arc or burn marks inside the microwave cavity:

If you’re not confident that you can repair the microwave on your own, schedule repair service.
Our technicians have the training and tools to diagnose these issues quickly and restore your appliance.

full_content.content: Frequently Asked QuestionsIs it worth repairing an over-the-range or built-in microwave?Yes, in many cases it is. Over-the-range and built-in microwaves typically last 9 to 15 years, and repairs are often much more affordable than full replacement. If the unit is under 10 years old and the repair cost is less than half the price of a new microwave, repair is usually the smart choice.Why is my microwave running but not heating food?This is often caused by a failed magnetron, diode, or capacitor, which are key components in generating heat. These repairs require a professional because microwaves store high voltage even when unplugged. full_content.content: Glossary TermsWhat is a Microwave Waveguide Cover?A microwave waveguide cover is a small, often mica or plastic piece inside the microwave that covers the opening where microwaves enter the cooking chamber, protecting the microwave's internal components from food splatter and ensuring efficient distribution of the microwaves.What is a Microwave Diode?A microwave diode is an electrical component that allows current to flow in one direction only, playing a crucial role in converting incoming electrical power into the microwave energy that cooks the food.What is a Microwave Sensor?A microwave sensor is a technologically advanced feature in modern microwave ovens that measures vapor (steam) emitted by the food, adjusting the cooking time and power levels automatically for optimal results.What is a Microwave Magnetron?A microwave magnetron is a component in microwave ovens that generates the microwaves used to cook food.
